title: Dielectric slab inserted into capacitor voltage

content.question: A parallel-plate capacitor is connected to a battery with potential difference <math alttext="epsilon" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>ϵ</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. The capacitor is allowed to fully charge and is disconnected. A dielectric material is then inserted between the capacitor plates, and a voltmeter is connected across the two plates. Which of the following is a correct prediction for the reading on the voltmeter?

choices.label: <math alttext="V is less than epsilon" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>V</mi><mo><</mo><mi>ϵ</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>
<math alttext="V is equal to epsilon" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>V</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>ϵ</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>
<math alttext="V is greater than epsilon" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>V</mi><mo>></mo><mi>ϵ</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>

Either <math alttext="V is less than epsilon" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>V</mi><mo><</mo><mi>ϵ</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> or <math alttext="V is greater than epsilon" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>V</mi><mo>></mo><mi>ϵ</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, depending on the original capacitance of the capacitor.

content.answer: <math alttext="V is less than epsilon" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>V</mi><mo><</mo><mi>ϵ</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>

skill.text: 2.C: Compare physical quantities between two or more scenarios or at different times and locations in a single scenario.
